Acetabular Loosening: The acetabular cup shows signs of loosening with radiolucent lines or migration between the cup and bone interface.
Dislocation: The hip prosthesis has dislocated with the femoral head displaced from the acetabular cup.
Fracture: There is a fracture visible in the bone structure around the hip prosthesis.
Good Place: The hip prosthesis is in good position with proper alignment and no signs of loosening or migration.
Native Hip: This is a native hip joint without any prosthetic components, showing normal anatomy.
Spacer: A temporary spacer is present in the hip joint, typically used during staged revision surgery.
Stem Loosening: The femoral stem shows signs of loosening with radiolucent lines or migration between the stem and bone interface.
Infection: There is evidence of infection in the hip prosthesis area.
Wear: There is evidence of wear in the hip prosthesis, typically seen as asymmetric joint space narrowing or particle debris.
